posts.cooked: Now that the season is over I am looking to start a new project to keep me busy. The project is a mini swerve drive that would be driven by an esp32. My goal with this build is to have a fully functioning swerve with leftover ports for additions to the bot that I may make later on. I have been thinking about how to limit the turn motors and have landed on keeping 2 (one for each set of diagonal wheels) because all diagonal wheels stay in the same angle (180deg offsets can be done for turns). This is not a design I feel extremely good about and I want to hear your ideas.

posts.name: Wilson
posts.cooked: If I understand correctly, that would theoretically work, except it would eliminate driving & spinning at the same time, or at least make it more difficult. But that‚Äôs not actually a huge issue when driving.

posts.name: Brandon McDonald
posts.cooked:
You should check out 9312‚Äôs turd swerve! @sthump can tell you more i‚Äôm sure but in the mean time check out their build thread that has the CAD & Code for it.

FRC 9312 NERD Spark - 2024 Build Thread Open Alliance
This is really cool! if anyone who worked on this could give some insight into how it was done pls feel free too. This is almost exactly what I wanted to do!

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked:
Everything is 3D printed.  All of the electronics and motors are FRC legal parts.  Programmed in JAVA.

We are working on building a list of COTS parts, hardware and building instructions.

Do you have access to a 3D printer?  How good are you at using CAD and specifically OnShape?

Also was thinking about building one how does it hold up structurally did you have to replace parts often? i saw it was a bit slow. did you do any trial of lowering the gear ratio(if that is the reason) or was there a different reason it looks slow?

I am an inventor CADer (What my school teaches) and I would say I am proficient (I have a level 1 certification). My bigger struggle is the code because I am a beginner programmer (I have done 3-4 projects). I do have a 3d printer and use it often. I am quite curious about how the 2 modules compares to having 4 and how the bot is revolving in the center of the robot with only 2 modules.
I saw they have a code example
I did a mini bot last year but this year I am aiming to level up with swerve.

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked:
It‚Äôs made of 3D printed parts so don‚Äôt play battlebots with it.  But it will survive as a teaching tool.

Pods are pretty easy to change out.  4 bolts and the whole pod comes off and a new one can be bolted on.

In terms of slow, the motors are current limited to 20 amps or so.   It will go faster if you really want it to.   Not sure what you would be teaching at that point other than you can run into people‚Äôs ankles at faster speeds.
Yes they do but if I am being honest I dont really understand the logic being how it works. I am not very good with code‚Ä¶ Ig thats y it is a teaching tool lmao

We are trying to make a ‚Äútraining‚Äù bot so as close to the real thing but that would would fit in our huge budget of having around the neighborhood of having no money

Plus faster robot looks cooler and cool thing are always good to get more students

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked:
The minimum number of pods required is 2.  Adding a 3rd or 4th pod just means you need to change the math a little bit.

There are only 2 to save on costs.  If you can control 2 pods, programming 3rd and 4th shouldn‚Äôt be a hard exercise.

Code is available here:

mini swervebot for code development and programming training - nerdspark/TurdSwerve

CAD here:

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

link_counts.title: GitHub - nerdspark/TurdSwerve: mini swervebot for code development and programming training

posts.cooked: 2 pods is perfect for what I am doing. Thx for the help. I will be working on putting the math into Arduino ide

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked:
The drive motor was speed limited to 1/4 speed cuz I am a bad driver. The gear ratio is approx. L3.5 so it should theoretically be really fast. We have not tested if the PLA gears will melt or something however

Kully:

having around the neighborhood of having no money

The entire chassis has only around $80 of parts (absolute encoders, wheels, shafts, bearings, screws) if you already have the electronics
